{{Infobox football club | clubname = Casar de Cáceres | image = | fullname = Agrupación Deportiva Casar de Cáceres | nickname = | founded = 2003[https://web.archive.org/web/20080413111005/http://www.adcasar.com/datosclub.php] | ground = Estadio Municipal,
[[Casar de Cáceres]], [[Extremadura]],
[[Spain]] | capacity = 400 sitting) | chairman = Marcelino Pacheco | manager = Juan Luis Frutos | league = Regional Preferente | season = 2012–13 | position = Regional Preferente, 5th | pattern_la1=_whiteshoulders|pattern_b1=_whiteshoulders |pattern_ra1=_whiteshoulders | leftarm1=FF0000|body1=FF0000|rightarm1=FF0000|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=FF0000| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF }} '''Agrupación Deportiva Casar de Cáceres''' is a [[List of football clubs in Spain|Spanish football team]] based in [[Casar de Cáceres]], in the autonomous community of [[Extremadura]]. Founded in 2003, it plays in ''[[Divisiones Regionales de Fútbol in Extremadura|Regional Preferente]]'', holding home games at ''Estadio Municipal de Casar de Cáceres''. ==Season to season== {| class="wikitable" |- !Season !Tier !Division !Place ![[Copa del Rey]] |- |style="background:#25A8F9;"|2008/09 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|6 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|1ª Reg. |style="background:#25A8F9;"|3rd | |- |style="background:#25A8F9;"|2009/10 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|6 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|1ª Reg. |style="background:#25A8F9;"|9th | |- |style="background:#25A8F9;"|2010/11 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|6 |style="background:#25A8F9;"|1ª Reg. |style="background:#25A8F9;"|2nd[http://www.hoycasardecaceres.es/actualidad/2011-05-16/a.d.casar-logra-sonado-ascenso-regional-1940.html La A.D.Casar logra el soñado ascenso a Regional Preferente] | |- |style="background:#CECE1B;"|2011/12 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|5 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|Reg. Pref. |style="background:#CECE1B;"|11th | |- |style="background:#CECE1B;"|2012/13 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|5 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|Reg. Pref. |style="background:#CECE1B;"|5th | |- |style="background:#CECE1B;"|2013/14 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|5 |style="background:#CECE1B;"|Reg. Pref. |style="background:#CECE1B;"|— | |} ---- *'''3''' seasons in ''Primera Regional'' *'''2''' seasons in ''Regional Preferente'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.futbolme.com/col/index_equipo.asp?id_equipo=3917 Futbolme.com profile]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[http://www.fexfutbol.com/pnfg/NPcd/NFG_VerClub?cod_primaria=1000118&codigo_club=2507 fexfutbol.com profile] {{DEFAULTSORT:Casar de Caceres}} [[Category:Football clubs in Spain]] [[Category:Divisiones Regionales de Fútbol clubs]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Spain]] {{Spain-stub}}

'''Agisymba''' was an unidentified country in [[Africa]] mentioned by [[Ptolemy]] in the middle of the 2nd century AD.
==Data==
According to Ptolemy's writings it was a 4 months journey south of the [[Fezzan]] and contained large animals, such as [[Rhinoceros|rhinoceroses]] and [[elephants]], as well as many tall mountains (probably the [[Tibesti]]). Agisymba was located near the [[lake Chad]], in those centuries bigger than what it is today.
Ptolemy's account is based on that written by [[Marinus of Tyre]] between 107 AD and 115 AD. Between the years 83 AD and 92 AD, the king of the [[Garamantes]] claimed that the Agisymba population were his subjects.
Modern historians suggest that Agisymba was probably somewhere to the north of [[Lake Chad]]<ref>[http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/brill-s-new-pauly/agisymba-e108180 Agisymba] on BrillOnLine Reference Works.</ref> as the [[Chad]] area is populated with many mountains. One theory is that Agisymba was an antecedent of the [[Kanem Empire]] located on the northern shore of Lake Chad. <ref>[http://dierklange.com/pdf/contents/12Mune-Symbol_as_the_Ark.pdf "The Mune as the Ark of the Covenant between Duguwa and Sefuwa (in ancient Kanem)"] Borno Museum Society Newsletter 66-67 (2006), 15-25. (The article has a map (page 6) of the ancient Central Sahara and proposes to identify Agisymba of 100 CE with the early Kanem state).</ref>
{{Quote|''In AD 90 a traveler, probably a trader called Julius Maternus, profiting from the improved relations between the Romans and the Garamantes at this time -no doubts as a result of Flaccus's success- made his way through the land of the Garamantes to the land of Agisymba, where there were rhinoceroses.'' JD. Fage (Cambridge history of Africa) <ref>Fage."Trans-Saharan contacts and west Africa". The Cambridge History of Africa.Volume 2 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=ZTNTz3POoZUC&pg=PA286&lpg=PA286&dq=balbus+expedition+in+sahara&source=bl&ots=qV9iDfzo4t&sig=c07yAoFsTwaGF4wRUUJbiVQ-O6Q&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwicxZ6Op4bRAhVCLSYKHfmgCUsQ6AEIJzAC#v=onepage&q=balbus%20expedition%20in%20sahara&f=false p.286])</ref>}}
Indeed Ptolomeus wrote that around 90 AD Julius Maternus (or Matiernus) did a mainly commercial expedition. From the Sirte gulf he reached the Oasis of Cufra and the Oasis of Archei, then arrived -after 4 months travelling with the king of the Garamantes- to the river Bahr Salamat and Bahr Aouk, near the actual Central African Republic in a region then called Agisymba. He went back to [[Rome]] with a rhinoceros with two horns, that was shown in the [[Colosseum]].<ref>[http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/brill-s-new-pauly/agisymba-e108180 Agisymba and Maternus]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[Jehan Desanges|Desanges, Jehan]], ''Recherches sur l'activité des méditerranéens aux confins de l'Afrique'', Rome 1978 (here: p. 197-213). * Huss, Werner: ''Agisymba'', New Pauly, vol I, Stuttgart 1996 (Sp 260). * Lange, Dierk, ''Ancient Kingdoms of West Africa'', Dettelbach 2004 (here: pp 280-4).
==See also==
*[[Romans in Sub-Saharan Africa]]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071022041741/http://dierklange.com/Classical_world-2-Hannover_2004de.pdf West Africa and the Classical World - neglected contexts "] in H. Bley''et al.''(Ed.),''in Africa Context: references in world history and the present'', 19 international meeting of the VAD, Hannover 2004, p. 20
[[Category:Countries in ancient Africa]] [[Category:Ancient peoples]] [[Category:History of Africa]] [[Category:African civilizations]] [[Category:History of Chad]]

revision.text:
{{infobox military award | name = Cross of Recognition
''Atzinības krusts'' | image = Atzinības krusts.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Grand Cross of the Cross of Recognition | awarded_by = {{LAT}} | country = | type = 5 class [[order (honour)|Order]], with honor medals in 5 grades. | eligibility = | for = Special services in public, cultural, science, sports and education. | campaign = | status = | description = | motto = Pour les bonnêtes gens
(For people of honour) | clasps = | post-nominals = | established = 1710
Reestablished 1938
Revived 2004 | first_award = | last_award = | total = | posthumous = | recipients = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = [[Order of Viesturs]] | same = | lower = Medal of Honour of the Order of Three Stars{{cite web|title=Chapter VIII of the Law on State Honours|url=http://www.president.lv/pk/content/?cat_id=7417|work=president.lv|publisher=Latvijas Valsts prezidenta kanceleja|accessdate=1 November 2011}} | related = | image2 = [[File:LVA Cross of Recognition.png|100px]] | caption2 = Ribbon bar of the cross }} The '''Cross of Recognition''' ({{lang-lv|Atzinības krusts}}) is a [[state decoration]] of [[Latvia]]. ==History== The decoration was established in 1710 in the [[Duchy of Courland and Semigallia]] by Duke [[Frederick William, Duke of Courland|Frederick William]] as a symbol of the then-established Order of Recognition (l’Ordre de la Reconnaissance). According to the order's statute, it was established “in thanks to God Almighty for the recovery of Courland after the [[Great Northern War]]” (“et in memoriam recuperatae Curlandiae”). The order was bestowed for outstanding civilian and military accomplishments.[https://www.president.lv/en/state-awards/the-cross-of-recognition State awards > The Cross of Recognition] - Official website of the [[President of Latvia]] Frederick William died in January 1711. No more than 18 people were awarded the order and its cross by then. After his death, no further orders were presented. The Cross of Recognition was reestablished by the [[Republic of Latvia]] in 1938. Five classes of the order and three medals of honour were introduced, as well as a separate first level for the medal. With the beginning of the [[Soviet occupation of Latvia in 1940|Soviet occupation of Latvia]], the bestowing of the order was halted. After the restoration of the independence of Latvia, the decoration was restored again as the Cross of Recognition in 2004. It is awarded to Latvians and foreigners for special services in public, cultural, science, sports and education.{{cite web|last=Robertson|first=Megan|title=Republic of Latvia: Cross of Recognition|url=http://medals.org.uk/latvia/1991-latvia/1991-latvia008.htm|work=Medals of the World|accessdate=12 November 2011}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.president.lv/ordeni/ordeni.html?&cat_ State Decorations of Latvia] {{Latvian honours}} [[Category:Orders, decorations, and medals of Latvia]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Recognition]] [[Category:Duchy of Courland and Semigallia]] {{Latvia-stub}} {{award-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox broadcasting network | network_name = Doordarshan Saptagiri | network_logo = [[File:Doordarshan.png|185px|Doordarshan Logo]] | country = [[India]] | network_type = [[Terrestrial and satellite television|Broadcast]] [[television network]] | available = India and parts of Asia,China and Gulf Countries. | owner = [[Prasar Bharati]] | launch_date = 1993-10-10 (as Doordarshan Kendra Hyderabad)
2014-9-27(as Doordarshan Kendra Vijayawada) | founder = [[Govt. of India]] | brand = DD (Doordarshan) | Frequency_details = INSAT-4B (KU) 93.5E 11150 V 27500 | headquarters = [[Vijayawada, India|Vijayawada]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]] | website = [http://www.ddsaptagiri.tv/vijayawada_kendra.html] }} '''DD Saptagiri''' ([[Telugu language|Telugu]]: దూరదర్శన్ సప్తగిరి) is a state-owned television channel telecasting in the [[Telugu language]] from a studio at [[Doordarshan]] Kendra [[Vijayawada]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], India. This studio was inaugurated by the Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, Shri [[N. Chandrababu Naidu]], on 27 September 2014. In addition to the terrestrial over-the-air transmission, the DD Vijayawada studio programmes are beamed through [[direct-broadcast satellite]] (DTH) and cable networks.{{cite web|url=http://www.ddfreedish.in/general-news/dd-free-dish-adds-dd-vijayawada |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140927125935/http://www.ddfreedish.in/general-news/dd-free-dish-adds-dd-vijayawada |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-09-27 |title=Doordarshan Kendra Vijayawada |publisher=ddfreedish.in |date= |accessdate=2014-09-27 }} Doordarshan Kendra Vijayawada’s Regional Network in Telugu took on a new identity as "DD Saptagiri", on 27 September 2014. This service is viewed not only in India, but also in some other parts of the world. The channel is named after the seven hills surrounding the world famous [[Tirumala Venkateswara Temple]] in [[Tirupati]] at the south of the state ('Sapta' in Sanskrit means seven and 'Giri' means mountain or hill). ==Popularity== Doordarshan [[Vijayawada]] was the only television channel broadcast from Andhra Pradesh after bifurcation of the state. Its programmes are aimed mainly at 13 districts of Andhra Pradesh. Since the '90s, DD Vijayawada has been a small studio facility through which programmes based on coastal Andhra are produced and used to be aired weekly once through DDK Hyderabad. It was launched by Andhra Pradesh CM Nara Chandhra Babu Naidu and Union Minister of Urban Development Shri [[Venkaiah Naidu]] on 27 September 2014. Venkaiah Naidu announced that the All India Radio Bhavan here was named [[Pingali Venkaiah]] Bhavan.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvhub.in/watch/etv2/chandrababu--venkaiah-jointly-launches-dd-sapthagiri-channel-in-vijayawada/x19Dqkib6N4/ |title=DD Saptagiri launch |date= |accessdate=2014-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006103548/http://www.tvhub.in/watch/etv2/chandrababu--venkaiah-jointly-launches-dd-sapthagiri-channel-in-vijayawada/x19Dqkib6N4/ |archivedate=6 October 2014 |df=dmy }} ==Frequency and satellite details from DD Free Dish== INSAT-4B (C-BAND)93.5E 4060 MHZ Horizontal, symbol rate- 4250, INSAT-4B (KU) 93.5E 11150 V 27500 ==Channel details from [[APSFL]]== Channel 064 on [[APSFL]] == See also== * [[All India Radio]] * [[DD Direct Plus]] * [[Prasar Bharati|Ministry of Information and Broadcasting]] * [[List of programs broadcast by DD National]] * [[List of South Asian television channels by country]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.ddsaptagiri.tv/vijayawada_kendra.html }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130726051932/http://www.ddindia.gov.in/ Doordarshan Official Internet site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130904045856/http://www.ddinews.gov.in/ Doordarshan news site] {{Telugu Language Television}} {{CATV}} {{Terrestrial television channels of India}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dd Saptagiri}} [[Category:Telugu-language television channels]] [[Category:Foreign television channels broadcasting in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1977]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Indian direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Doordarshan]] [[Category:Television stations in Andhra Pradesh]]

revision.text:
{{Time zones of Europe}} {{Time zones of the Middle East}} '''Eastern European Summer Time''' ('''EEST''') is one of the names of [[UTC+3]] [[time zone]], 3 hours ahead of [[Coordinated Universal Time]]. It is used as a summer [[daylight saving time]] in some [[Europe]]an and [[Middle East]]ern countries, which makes it the same as [[Arabia Standard Time]], [[East Africa Time]] and [[Moscow Time]]. During the winter periods, [[Eastern European Time]] ([[UTC2|UTC+2]]) is used.
Since 1996 [[European Summer Time]] has been observed from the last Sunday in March to the last Sunday in October; previously the rules were not uniform across the European Union.<ref name=Myers>{{Cite web |author=Joseph Myers |title=History of legal time in Britain |url=http://www.srcf.ucam.org/~jsm28/british-time/ |accessdate=2009-10-11 |date=2009-07-17 }}</ref>
==Usage== The following countries and territories use '''Eastern European Summer Time''' during the summer:
* [[Belarus]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–89, regular EEST from 1991-2011 * [[Bulgaria]], regular EEST since 1979 * [[Cyprus]], regular EEST since 1979 ([[Northern Cyprus]] stopped using EEST in 2016, but returned to EEST on 25 March 2018) * [[Estonia]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–88, regular EEST since 1989 * [[Finland]], regular EEST since 1981 * [[Greece]], regular EEST since 1975 * [[Israel]], [[Israel Daylight Time]] since 1948 (which tracks EEST when the two overlap) * [[Jordan]], since 1985 * [[Latvia]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–88, regular EEST since 1989 * [[Lebanon]], since 1984 * [[Lithuania]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–88, regular EEST since 1989, apart from MKIAEL nossniNtrrRamars 1998-2003 when it was [[Central European Summer Time]] * [[Moldova]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1932–40 and 1981–89, regular EEST since 1991 * [[Romania]], unofficial EEST in years 1932–40, regular EEST since 1979 * [[Russia]] ([[Kaliningrad Oblast|Kaliningrad]]), [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–90, regular EEST since 1991, as standard time from March 2011. * [[Syria]], since 1983 * [[Ukraine]], [[Moscow Summer Time]] in years 1981–89, regular EEST from 1992<ref name="Kyivwintertimeisback">[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/115146/ Ukraine to return to standard time on Oct. 30 (updated)], [[Kyiv Post]] (October 18, 2011)</ref>
In one year 1991 EEST was used also in [[Moscow]] and [[Samara Oblast|Samara]] time zones of [[Russia]]. [[Egypt]] has previously used EEST from 1957–2010 and 2014–2015. [[Turkey]], has previously used EEST from 1970-1978 EEST, [[Moscow Summer Time]] from 1979–1983, and EEST from 1985-2016.
{{clear}} {| cellpadding="4" align="right" class="wikitable" style="width:300px;margin-right:0px;" ! Colour !! Legal time vs local mean time |- | style="background: #8f8fbf;" | | 1 h ± 30 m behind |- | style="background: #bfbfbf;" | | 0 h ± 30 m |- | style="background: #bf8f8f;" | | 1 h ± 30 m ahead |- | style="background: #bf6060;" | | 2 h ± 30 m ahead |- | style="background: #bf0000;" | | 3 h ± 30 m ahead |} [[Image:Tzdiff-Europe-summer.png|thumb|300px|European summer]]
==See also== * [[European Summer Time]] * [[UTC+3]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Time zones]] [[Category:Time in Europe]] [[Category:Geography of Eastern Europe]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder |honorific-prefix = |name = Frans Andriessen |honorific-suffix = [[Order of the Netherlands Lion|KNL]] [[Order of Orange-Nassau|KGCON]] |image = Frans Andriessen 1979 (1).jpg |imagesize = 250px |caption = Frans Andriessen in 1979 |office = [[European Commissioner for External Relations|European Commissioner for
External Relations]] and [[European Commissioner for Trade|Trade]] |term_start = 6 January 1989 |term_end = 6 January 1993 |president = [[Jacques Delors]] |predecessor = [[Willy De Clercq]] |successor = [[Hans van den Broek]]
(External relations)
[[Leon Brittan]] (Trade) |office1 = [[Vice-President of the European Commission#First Vice-President|First Vice-President of the
European Commission]] |term_start1 = 6 January 1985 |term_end1 = 6 January 1993 |president1 = [[Jacques Delors]] |predecessor1 = [[Christopher Tugendhat]] |successor1 = [[Martin Bangemann]] |office2 = [[European Commissioner for Agriculture and Rural Development|European Commissioner for
Agriculture]] and [[European Commissioner for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries|Fisheries]] |term_start2 = 6 January 1985 |term_end2 = 6 January 1989 |president2 = [[Jacques Delors]] |predecessor2 = [[Poul Dalsager]] |successor2 = [[Ray MacSharry]] (Agriculture)
[[Manuel Marin]] (Fisheries) |office3 = [[European Commissioner for Competition|European Commissioner for
Parliamentary Relations and Competition]] |term_start3 = 6 January 1981 |term_end3 = 6 January 1985 |president3 = [[Gaston Thorn]] |predecessor3 = [[Raymond Vouel]] |successor3 = [[Grigoris Varfis]]
(Parliamentary Relations)
[[Peter Sutherland]] (Competition) |office4 = [[Senate (Netherlands)|Member of the Senate]] |term_start4 = 16 September 1980 |term_end4 = 6 January 1981 |parliamentarygroup4= [[Catholic People's Party]]
(1980)
[[Christian Democratic Appeal]]
(1980–1981) |office5 = [[List of Ministers of Finance of the Netherlands|Minister of Finance]] |term_start5 = 19 December 1977 |term_end5 = 22 February 1980 |primeminister5 = [[Dries van Agt]] |predecessor5 = [[Wim Duisenberg]] |successor5 = [[Gijs van Aardenne]] (''Ad interim'') |office6 = [[Catholic People's Party#Leaders|Leader of the Catholic People's Party]] |term_start6 = 1 October 1971 |term_end6 = 25 May 1977 |predecessor6 = [[Gerard Veringa]] |successor6 = ''Office abolished'' |office7 = [[Parliamentary leader]] in the
[[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] |term_start7 = 16 August 1971 |term_end7 = 25 May 1977 |predecessor7 = [[Gerard Veringa]] |successor7 = ''Office abolished'' |parliamentarygroup7= [[Catholic People's Party]] |office8 = [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|Member of the House of Representatives]] |term_start8 = 23 February 1967 |term_end8 = 19 December 1977 |parliamentarygroup8= [[Catholic People's Party]] |birthname = Franciscus Henricus Johannes Joseph Andriessen |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1929|04|02|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Utrecht]], [[Netherlands]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Netherlands|Dutch]] |party = [[Christian Democratic Appeal]]
(from 1980) |otherparty = [[Catholic People's Party]]
(until 1980) |spouse = {{marriage|Catherine Andriessen|1959}} |children = |residence = [[Utrecht]], [[Netherlands]] |alma_mater = [[Utrecht University]]
([[Bachelor of Laws]], [[Master of Laws]]) |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Civil service|Civil servant]] · [[Jurist]] · [[Research]]er · [[Professor]] |signature = |website = }} '''Franciscus Henricus Johannes Joseph "Frans" Andriessen''' (born 2 April 1929) is a retired [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[Christian Democratic Appeal]] (CDA). In 1967 he was first elected to the [[House of Representatives of the Netherlands|House of Representatives]] for the [[Katholieke Volkspartij]] (KVP). From 1971 to 1977 he was leader of the KVP.[https://www.cda.nl/mensen/toon/frans-andriessen/ Biography on CDA website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427112400/https://www.cda.nl/mensen/toon/frans-andriessen/ |date=27 April 2015 }} In 1977, the KVP merged with two protestant parties to form the Christen-Democratisch Appel (CDA). For the CDA, he served as [[Finance minister|Minister of Finance]] (1977–1980) and [[European Commissioner]] for Competition (1981-1985), Agriculture (1985-1989), and External Relations and Trade (1989–1993).[http://www.cvce.eu/en/collections/unit-content/-/unit/02bb76df-d066-4c08-a58a-d4686a3e68ff/bd9ec6da-ccd8-4e2d-b570-c1e855d2513c/Resources#19ab80a5-8188-422a-b1aa-6cbc0219ebee_en&overlay Image on CVCE website] He is one of few politicians to serve three consecutive terms as an EU Commissioner.{{cite web | url=https://www.politico.eu/article/national-beauty-contest-for-next-commission-chief/ | title=National beauty contest for next Commission chief | date=11 February 2004 | author=European Voice - Entre-Nous column | accessdate=10 November 2018 }} ==Decorations== {| class="wikitable" style="width:60%;" |- style="background:#ccf; text-align:center;" | colspan=5 |'''Honours''' |- ! style="width:80px;"| Ribbon bar !! Honour !! Country !! Date !! Comment |- | [[File:NLD Order of the Dutch Lion - Knight BAR.png|80px]] | [[Order (distinction)|Knight]] of the [[Order of the Netherlands Lion]] | Netherlands | 15 May 1980 | |- | [[File:BEL Order of Leopold II - Grand Cross BAR.png|80px]] | [[Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of Leopold II]] | [[Belgium]] | 15 December 1990 | |- | [[File:NLD Order of Orange-Nassau - Knight Grand Cross BAR.png|80px]] | [[Grand Cross|Knight Grand Cross]] of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] | Netherlands | 30 April 1993 | |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} ;Official * {{nl icon}} [https://www.parlement.com/id/vg09lkxehrzx/f_h_j_j_frans_andriessen Mr. F.H.J.J. (Frans) Andriessen] Parlement & Politiek * {{nl icon}} [https://www.eerstekamer.nl/persoon/mr_f_h_j_j_andriessen_cda Mr. F.H.J.J. Andriessen (CDA)] Eerste Kamer der Staten-Generaal {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before=[[Gerard Veringa]]|rows=2}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Parliamentary leader]] of the

revision.text:
{{Infobox building |name = Gildo Pastor Center |image = |location = 7, Rue du Gabian, Fontvieille, Monaco |coordinates = {{coord|43.729498|7.414689|display=it}} |status = Complete |start_date = |completion_date = |building_type = |architectural_style = Modernist |roof = |floor_count = 12 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = |architect = |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = |owner = |management = |references = }} The '''Gildo Pastor Center''' is a high-rise commercial building in [[Monaco]].
==Location== It is located at number 7 on the Rue du Gabian in [[Fontvieille, Monaco]].<ref name="emporiscenter">[http://www.emporis.com/building/gildopastorcenter-monaco-monaco Gildo Pastor Center], [[Emporis]]</ref>
==History== The construction of the building was carried out by Monegasque heir [[Gildo Pallanca Pastor]].<ref name="venturi">[http://en.venturi.fr/corporate/presentation/gildo-pallanca-pastor Venturi: Gildo Pallanca Pastor]</ref> The building was owned by his mother, heiress [[Hélène Pastor]].<ref name="helenepastorpallanca">[http://www.hpp.mc/groupe.html Hélène Pastor Pallanca: Le Gildo Pastor Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127084202/http://www.hpp.mc/groupe.html |date=2015-01-27 }}</ref> It was named in honor of her father, [[Gildo Pastor]].<ref name="venturi"/> It served as the headquarters of her eponymous real estate company.<ref>[http://www.chambre-immo.monte-carlo.mc/en/listing/197-gildo-pastor-center/ Chambre Immobilière Monégasque: Gildo Pastor Center]</ref>
It is 125.82 ft. high, with twelve storeys.<ref name="emporiscenter"/> It was built with concrete and designed in the [[modernist architecture|modernist]] architectural style.<ref name="emporiscenter"/> Underneath the building, there are three flights of underground parking, with 900 parking spaces.<ref name="emporiscenter"/><ref name="helenepastorpallanca"/>
The building is home to a restaurant named ''Le Bureau''.<ref name="helenepastorpallanca"/> It is also rented out as corporate offices to companies such as [[Gestion Maritime]].<ref name="helenepastorpallanca"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Gestion Maritime S.A.M |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=546343996 |website=Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref> For example, it houses the offices of [[Avinco]], a helicopter company, [[Oceanco]], a yacht retailer, and [[GasLog]], a shipping company.<ref>[http://www.avinco.net/helicopters/news/we've-moved!.html Avinco: We've moved!]</ref><ref>[http://www.oceancoyacht.com/contact Oceanco: Contact]</ref><ref>[http://www.gaslogltd.com/contact GasLog: Contact]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Commercial buildings in Monaco]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Monaco]] [[Category:Pastor family]]
{{Monaco-struct-stub}}

{{Infobox single | Name = Gotta Thing About You | Cover = FO&O_-_Gotta_Thing_About_You.jpg | Artist = [[FO&O]] | from Album = FO&O | Released = 26 February 2017 | Format = [[Music download|Digital download]] | Recorded = 2016 | Genre = {{Hlist|[[Electropop]]}} | Length = 2:56 | Label = Artist House Stockholm | Writer = {{hlist|[[Robert John "Mutt" Lange|Robert "Mutt" Lange]]|[[Tony Nilsson]]}} | Producer = | Last single = "[[Who Doesn't Love Love]]"
(2016) | This single = "'''Gotta Thing About You'''"
(2017) | Next single = "[[So So Good]]"
(2017) | Misc = }} "'''Gotta Thing About You'''" is a song recorded by Swedish boyband [[FO&O]]. The song was released as a digital download in [[Sweden]] on 26 February 2017 and peaked at number 10 on the [[Sverigetopplistan|Swedish Singles Chart]]. It is taking part in [[Melodifestivalen 2017]], and qualified to andra chansen from the third semi-final on 18 February 2017. The song qualified from andra chansen on 4 March 2017. It was written by [[Robert John "Mutt" Lange|Robert "Mutt" Lange]] and [[Tony Nilsson]].{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2017/02/18/two-artists-qualify-melodifestivalen-final/|title=TWO MORE ARTISTS QUALIFY TO THE MELODIFESTIVALEN FINAL|date=18 February 2017|publisher=Eurovoix|website=eurovoix.com|author=The NPBC}} ==Track listing== {{Track listing | headline = Digital download{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/se/album/gotta-thing-about-you-single/id1203207237|title=Gotta Thing About You - Single|publisher=iTunes|accessdate=23 February 2017}} | title1 = Gotta Thing About You | length1 = 2:56 }} ==Charts== ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! Chart (2017) ! Peak
position |- ! scope="row"| Sweden ([[Sverigetopplistan]]){{cite web|url=http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/|title=Sverigetopplistan - Sveriges Officiella Topplista|publisher=[[Sverigetopplistan]]|accessdate=18 March 2017}} | 7 |} ===Year-end charts=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! Chart (2017) ! Position |- ! scope="row"| Sweden (Sverigetopplistan){{cite web|url=http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/netdata/ghl002.mbr/lista?liid=43&dfom=20170001|title=Årslista Singlar – År 2017|publisher=[[Sverigetopplistan]]|language=Swedish|accessdate=16 January 2018}} | 97 |} ==Release history== {| class=wikitable ! Region ! Date ! Format ! Label |- | [[Sweden]] | 26 February 2017 | [[Music download|Digital download]] | Artist House Stockholm |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2017 singles]] [[Category:2016 songs]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen songs of 2017]] [[Category:FO&O songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Tony Nilsson]] [[Category:Songs written by Robert John "Mutt" Lange]] {{Sweden-stub}} {{2010s-single-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=January 2010}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 21 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]]s | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 2012-045A | SATCAT = | mission_duration = 15 years | spacecraft_bus = [[BSS-702MP]] | manufacturer = [[Boeing Satellite Systems]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|19 August 2012, 06:54:59|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Zenit-3SL]] | launch_site = [[Odyssey (launch platform)|Odyssey]] | launch_contractor = [[Sea Launch]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = 24 hours | orbit_longitude = 58° West | apsis = gee | trans_band = 40 IEEE [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]
40 IEEE {{ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Canada]]
[[United States]]
[[Latin America]]
[[Caribbean]]
[[Europe]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = [[Intelsat]] | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 20]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 22]] }} '''Intelsat 21''' is a [[communications satellite]] manufactured by [[Boeing]] Space Systems for the [[Intelsat|Intelsat Corp]], based on the [[BSS-702MP]] platform.{{cite web |url=http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/702/intelsat/intelsat.html |title=Boeing 702MP Fleet - Intelsat |publisher=Boeing |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208103816/http://www.boeing.com/defense-space/space/bss/factsheets/702/intelsat/intelsat.html |archivedate=2013-02-08 |df= }} It was launched in August 2012 from a mobile platform in the equatorial Pacific Ocean.{{cite web|last=Miramar-Garcia|first=Gabriel|title=Intelsat launches satellite for Latin America TV capacity|url=http://www.rapidtvnews.com/index.php/2012082023626/intelsat-launches-satellite-for-latin-america-tv-capacity.html|publisher=Rapid TV News|accessdate=28 January 2013}}http://www.satlaunch.net/p/launch-schedule-2012.html and replaces the [[Intelsat 9]] satellite at 58° West [[Longitude]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 2012}} [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] [[Category:Satellites using the BSS-702 bus]] [[Category:Communications satellites in geostationary orbit]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2012]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Organizations with year of establishment missing]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]

revision.text:
[[File:Klaipeda Castle Jazz Festival 2006.jpg|thumb|right|XIII Klaipėda Castle Jazz Festival]] The '''Klaipėda Castle Jazz Festival''' has been held annually during June or July in [[Klaipėda]], [[Lithuania]] since 1994. It is staged near the ruined [[Klaipėda Castle]].
Major international performers at past festivals have included [[Maynard Ferguson]], [[Toots Thielemans]], [[Billy Cobham]] Culture Mix, [[Mike Mainieri]], [[Victor Bailey (musician)|Victor Bailey]], [[Chico & the Gypsies]], [[Soweto Kinch]], [[Alex Wilson (musician)|Alex Wilson]], and [[Nikki Yeoh]], among others. It traditionally features an all-night [[jam session]].
==References== * [http://www.jazz.lt/www/festivalis/istorija/favorites/ Performers]. Klaipeda Jazz Festival - Official website. * [http://www.baltictimes.com/news/articles/18274/ Jazzing it up in Lithuania’s ‘New Orleans’]. [[Baltic Times]].
{{DEFAULTSORT:Klaipeda Castle Jazz Festival}} [[Category:Jazz festivals in Lithuania]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Music in Klaipėda]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1994]] [[Category:Annual events in Lithuania]] [[Category:Events in Klaipėda]] [[Category:Summer events in Lithuania]]
{{lithuania-stub}}

page.title: Leading Group on Innovative Financing for Development

revision.comment: removed [[Category:International development]]; added [[Category:International development agencies]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox Geopolitical organization |name = Leading Group on Innovative Financing for Development |linking_name = the Leading Group on Innovative Financing for Development |symbol_type = Logo |image_symbol = LeadingGroupLogo.jpg |symbol_width = 150px |image_map = |map_caption = |membership = {{unbulleted list |55 member states |4 observer states |{{longlabel|16 international
{{pad|1.0em}}organizations}} |Several [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]]s}} |admin_center_type = Secretariat |admin_center = {{nowrap|{{flagicon|France}} [[Paris]], [[France]]}} |leader_title1 = {{nowrap|Secretary General}} |leader_name1 = Julien Meimon |established_event1 = {{nowrap|as the "Leading Group
on Solidarity Levies to
Fund Development"}} |established_date1 =
1 March 2006 |established_event2 = as current name |established_date2 = June 2009 |official_website = http://www.leadinggroup.org }} The '''Leading Group on Innovative Financing for Development''' is a global platform made up of 55 member countries with differing levels of development, operating alongside international organisations and NGOs. Formerly known as the Leading Group on Solidarity Levies to Fund Development, the Leading Group seeks to promote the implementation and definition of [[innovative financing]] mechanisms around the world. Formed in 2006, the Leading Group is coordinated by the Permanent Secretariat which is located in Paris at the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (France)|French Ministry of Foreign and European Affairs]]. == Membership == The following countries are currently members of the Leading Group:
Algeria, Bangladesh, Belgium, Benin, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Cambodia, Cameroon, Cape Verde, Central African Republic, Chile, Congo, Cote d’Ivoire, Cyprus, Djibouti, Ethiopia, European Commission, Finland, France, Gabon, Germany, Great Britain, Guatemala, Guinea, Haiti, India, Italy, Japan, Jordan, Lebanon, Liberia, Luxembourg, Madagascar, Mali, Mauritania, Mauritius, Mexico, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Nicaragua, Niger, Nigeria, Poland, the Republic of Korea, Romania, Sao Tome and Principe, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Sierra Leone, South Africa, Spain, Togo, and Uruguay.
The following countries serve as observer countries in the Leading Group:
Austria, China, Egypt and Romania
The following international organisations are currently members of the Leading Group: *[[United Nations]] *[[African Development Bank]] *[[World Bank]] *[[Inter-American Development Bank]] *[[Asian Development Bank]] *[[FAO]] *[[International Monetary Fund]] *[[United Nations Population Fund]] (UNPF) *[[The Global Fund]] *[[OECD]] *[[WHO]] *[[UNAIDS]] *[[WFP]] *[[International Fund for Agricultural Development]] (IFAD) *[[United Nations Procurement Division]] (UNPD) *[[UNICEF]] == External links == *{{en icon}} [http://www.leadinggroup.org/rubrique20.html Official website] *{{fr icon}} [http://www.leadinggroup.org/rubrique1.html Le site officiel] *{{es icon}} [http://www.leadinggroup.org/rubrique192.html Página web oficial] [[Category:Economic development organizations]] [[Category:International development agencies]] [[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2006]] [[Category:Organizations based in Paris]]

revision.comment: per [[WP:CFDS]], replaced: Category:Knight Commanders of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany → Category:Knights Commander of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Martin Bangemann | image =Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F055742-0020, Bonn, FDP-Europawahlkampf, Bangemann.jpg | caption =Bangemann in 1979 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1934|11|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Wanzleben]], [[Province of Saxony|Saxony]] | residence = | nationality= German | death_date = | death_place = | office =[[Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (Germany)|Federal Minister of Economics]]
[[West Germany]] | term_start = 27 June 1984 | term_end = 1989 | predecessor = [[Otto Graf Lambsdorff]] | successor = [[Helmut Haussmann]] | office2 = Chairman of the FDP | term_start2 = 1985 | term_end2 = 1988 | predecessor2 = [[Hans-Dietrich Genscher]] | successor2 = [[Otto Graf Lambsdorff]] | party = [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|FDP]] | religion = | occupation =Lawyer | alma_mater = [[University of Tübingen]]
[[University of Munich]] | majority = | spouse = | children = 5 }} [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1986-0317-027, Berlin, Gespräch Honecker, Bangemann.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Bangemann (left) with [[Erich Honecker]] in Berlin 1986.]] '''Martin Bangemann''' (born 15 November 1934 in [[Wanzleben]]) is a German politician and a former leader of the [[Free Democratic Party of Germany|FDP]] (1985–1988). He studied Law in [[Tübingen]] and [[Munich]], earned a [[Doctor of law|Dr. jur.]] (not equivalent to [[Juris Doctor|J.S.D.]] , but a PhD in Law) in 1962 with a dissertation entitled "Bilder und Fiktionen in Recht und Rechtswissenschaft" ("Imagery and fiction in law and jurisprudence"). He qualified as an attorney in 1964. ==Career== Bangemann was a member of the [[European Parliament]] from 1973 to 1984, from 1976 to 1979 he was vice-chairman, from 1979 to 1984 chairman of the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (European Parliament group)|Liberal and Democratic Group]]. Moreover, he was vice-chair of the Committee on Budgets from 1978 to 1979.http://www.europarl.europa.eu/members/archive/alphaOrder/view.do?language=EN&id=933 Bangemann was the German Federal Minister of Economics from 1984 to 1988. In 1988, Bangemann joined the [[European Commission]]. He was Commissioner for the internal market and industrial affairs in the [[Delors Commission]] from 1989 to 1995. He was then Commissioner for Industrial affairs, Information & Telecommunications Technologies in the [[Santer Commission]] from 1995 to 1999. As commissioner he led a "high-level group" that drew up the report "Europe and the Global Information Society" in 1994.[http://www.echo.lu/eudocs/en/bangemann.html Europe and the global information society: Recommendations to the European Council]. Version hosted on I*M Europe, by Directorate-General XIII of the European Commission."[http://aei.pitt.edu/1199/ Report on Europe and the Global Information Society: Recommendations of the High-level Group on the Information Society to the Corfu European Council. Bulletin of the European Union, Supplement No. 2/94.]" University of Pittsburgh - Archive of European Integration (AEI). This document contained recommendations to the European Council on the measures that Europe should take regarding information infrastructure. It became known as the "Bangemann report" and influenced many EU policies.{{cite book |first=Hugh |last=Mackay |first2=Wendy |last2=Maples |first3=Paul |last3=Reynolds |title=Investigating the Information Society |location=London/New York |publisher=Routledge & The Open University |year=2001 |isbn=0-415-26831-1 |page=8 }} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Walter|first=Franz|editor1-last=Forkmann|editor1-first=Daniela|editor2-last=Schlieben|editor2-first=Michael|title=Die Parteivorsitzenden in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland 1949–2005|trans-title=The Party Chairmen of the Federal Republic of Germany 1949–2005|series=Göttinger Studien zur Parteiforschung|date=June 2005|publisher=VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften|location=|language=|isbn=3-531-14516-9|pages=151–154|chapter=Die Integration der Individualisten. Parteivorsitzende in der FDP|trans-chapter=The Integration of the Individualists. Party Chairmen in the FDP}} *{{cite book|last= Dittberner|first= Jürgen|title=Die FDP: Geschichte, Personen, Organisation, Perspektiven ; eine Einführung|trans-title=The FDP: History, People, Organization, Perspectives; an Introduction|year=2005|publisher=VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften|language=German|isbn=3-531-14050-7|page=72}} * {{cite web| url= http://www.europarl.europa.eu/members/archive/alphaOrder/view.do?language=EN&id=933| title= MEP Profile:Martin Bangemann| publisher=[[European Parliament]]| accessdate = 25 September 2010}} * {{cite web| url= http://ec.europa.eu/archives/1995_99/commissioners/en/bange.htm| title= Martin Bangemann| publisher=[[European Commission]]| accessdate = 25 September 2010}} {{commons category}} {{Economy Ministers of Germany}} {{FDP chairs}} {{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bangemann, Martin}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Economy ministers of Germany]] [[Category:Free Democratic Party (Germany) politicians]] [[Category:German European Commissioners]] [[Category:Members of the Bundestag for Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] {{Germany-politician-stub}} {{EU-org-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: embed authority control with wikidata information

revision.text:
{{Infobox station | name = [[File:Sofia Metro Logo.svg|30px|left|link=Sofia Metro]] Nadezhda | type = | style = Sofia Metro | image = Nadejda - 001.jpg | image_caption = | address = | coordinates = {{Coord|42|43|41.06|N|23|18|3.17|E|type:railwaystation_region:BG-23|display=inline,title}} | line = <!-- line information is detailed under "services" --> | other = | structure = sub-surface | platform = side | depth = | levels = 2 | tracks = 2 | parking = | bicycle = | baggage_check = | opened = 31-Aug-2012 | closed = | rebuilt = | electrified = | ADA = | code = 2993; 2994 | owned = [[Sofia#Administration|Sofia Municipality]] | zone = | smartcardname = | smartcardstatus = | former = | passengers = | pass_year = | pass_percent = | pass_system = | mpassengers = | services = {{s-rail|title=Sofia Metro}} {{s-line|system=Sofia Metro|line=Line 2|previous=Han Kubrat|next=Beli Dunav}} | map_locator = [[File:Map8 eng trans.png|300px]] | web = }} {{Sofia Metro Blue line}} '''Nadezhda Metro Station''' ({{lang-bg|Метростанция „Надежда“}}) is a station on the [[Sofia Metro]] in [[Bulgaria]]. It was put into operation on August 31, 2012. Bulgaria's PM [[Boyko Borisov]] and the [[President of the European Commission]] [[Jose Manuel Barroso]] inaugurated the new section of the Sofia Metro, which was funded with EU money. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=142808 |title=Bulgaria: Sofia Expands Its Metro, Barroso Pleased |publisher=Novinite.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n286275 |title=Jose Manuel Barroso: Sofia subway’s new line is an example of what can be expected from Europe |publisher=Focus-fen.net |date= |accessdate=2012-09-01}}</ref>
==Public Transportation== * [[Public buses in Sofia|City Bus service]]: 86
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Надежда 2.jpg| </gallery> * [http://vijsofia.eu/bg/%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8/%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F-2-%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F-3-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B0-31 vijsofia.eu]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|Nadezhda (Sofia Metro)|Nadezhda Metro Station}} *{{Facebook|ms.nadezhda|Nadezhda Metro Station}} * [http://www.metropolitan.bg/ Sofia Metropolitan] * [http://vijsofia.eu/bg/%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82%D0%B8/%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F-2-%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BD%D1%86%D0%B8%D1%8F-3-%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%B4%D0%B0-31/ More info in Bulgarian]

{{infobox book | | name = Nightmare | title_orig = Košmar | image = | caption = | author = [[Zlatko Topčić]] | cover_artist = | country = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
[[Turkey]] ([[Istanbul]])
[[Slovenia]] ([[Novo Mesto]]) | language = [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]]
[[Turkish language|Turkish]]
[[Slovenian language|Slovenian]] | series = | genre = | publisher = | release_date = | media_type = | pages = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Nightmare''''' ({{lang-bs|Košmar}}) is a contemporary Bosnian [[bestseller]] novel by [[Zlatko Topčić]] published in 1997. Novel set the guidelines and became a model of the other Bosnian novels. It received the prestigious Annual Award of the Association of Writers of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It was translated into [[Turkish language|Turkish]] (Saray Bosna da kabus, Gendas, [[Istanbul]], 1998) and [[Slovenian language|Slovenian]] (Mora, Založba Goga, [[Novo Mesto]], 2003).{{cite web|url=http://www.ntv.ba/knjiga-sedmice-kosmar-zlatko-topcic/|title=KNJIGA SEDMICE: „KOŠMAR“ Zlatko Topčić|work=ntv.ba|date=1 October 2014|accessdate=7 July 2017}} ==Characters== *Adi Solak, an intellectual, a journalist, a critic, an essayist
*Aca Nikolić, Solak's double, Chetnik Duke ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nightmare}} [[Category:1997 novels]] [[Category:20th century in fiction]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina culture]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina literature]] [[Category:Novels set in Bosnia and Herzegovina]] {{1990s-novel-stub}} {{Europe-novel-stub}}

page.title: President of the Court of Appeal of Malaysia

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox official post | post = President of the Court of Appeal | body = Malaysia | native_name = | insignia = Coat of arms of Malaysia.svg | insigniasize = | insigniacaption = | image = | imagesize = | incumbent = [[Ahmad Maarop|Ahmad Haji Maarop]] | incumbentsince = 11 July 2018 | department = | style = [[Malay titles|Yang Amat Arif]]
{{small|(The Very Wise)}} | member_of = [[Federal Court of Malaysia]] | reports_to = | residence = | seat = [[Palace of Justice, Putrajaya|Palace of Justice]], [[Putrajaya]] | nominator = [[Prime Minister of Malaysia]] | appointer = [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] | appointer_qualified = | termlength = mandatory retirement age at 65 or 66 (at request for minimal extension), extension retirement age at 68 or 70. | constituting_instrument = [[Constitution of Malaysia|Federal Constitution of Malaysia]] | formation = | inaugural = [[Lamin Haji Mohd Yunos]] | deputy = | salary = | website = {{URL|http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/}} }} The '''President of the Court of Appeal of Malaysia''' (Malay: ''Presiden Mahkamah Rayuan''), is the office and title of the deputy head of the Malaysian judiciary system. The title has been in use since 24 June 1994, when the [[Court of Appeal of Malaysia]] was formed. The President of the Court of Appeal is the head of the Court of Appeal, the second highest court of Malaysia. It is the second highest position in Malaysian judicial system after the [[Chief Justice of Malaysia]] and followed by the [[Chief Judge of Malaya]], and the [[Chief Judge of Sabah and Sarawak]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/courts/maljudiciary.shtml#Ope|title=The Malaysian Judiciary: Operation of the court|publisher=Malaysian Court|accessdate=15 April 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709144745/http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/courts/maljudiciary.shtml|archivedate=9 July 2011|deadurl=yes}} == Presidents of the Court of Appeal of Malaysia == * [[Lamin Haji Mohd Yunos]] (1994 to 2001){{cite web|url=http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/en/court/appeal-court/former-presidents-court-appeal|accessdate=17 October 2018|title=Former Presidents of the Court of Appeal|publisher=Official Website Office of the Chief Registrar Federal Court of Malaysia|date=12 October 2018}} * [[Wan Adnan Ismail]] (2001){{cite web|url=http://ww1.utusan.com.my/utusan/info.asp?y=2001&dt=0907&pub=Utusan_Express&sec=Front_Page&pg=fp_02.htm|date=7 September 2001|publisher=[[Utusan Malaysia]]|accessdate=17 October 2018|title=Zaki is new Chief Justice (updated)|work=Shaila Koshy}} * [[Ahmad Fairuz Abdul Halim]] (2002 to 2003) * [[Abdul Malik Ahmad]] (2004 to 2007) * [[Abdul Hamid Mohamad]] (2007) * [[Zaki Azmi]] (2007 to 2008){{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2008/10/16/zaki-is-new-chief-justice-updated/|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|accessdate=17 October 2018|title=Zaki is new Chief Justice (updated)|work=Shaila Koshy}} * [[Alauddin Mohd Sheriff]] (2008 to 2011) * [[Md Raus Sharif]] (2011 to 2017){{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/9/6/nation/9431247&sec=nation|title=Arifin appointed Chief Justice|publisher=The Star|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=11 September 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922224855/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F9%2F6%2Fnation%2F9431247&sec=nation|archivedate=22 September 2012|deadurl=yes}} * [[Zulkefli Ahmad Makinudin]] (2017 to 2018){{cite web|title=Md Raus appointed new Chief Justice|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/04/01/new-chief-justice/ |publisher=The Star |accessdate=1 April 2017 }} * [[Ahmad Maarop|Ahmad Haji Maarop]] (2018 to present){{cite web|url=https://www.bharian.com.my/berita/nasional/2018/07/448012/richard-malanjum-ketua-hakim-negara-yang-baharu|title=Richard Malanjum Ketua Hakim Negara yang baharu|work=Bernama|publisher=Berita Harian|date=11 July 2018|accessdate=12 July 2018}} == See also == * [[Courts of Malaysia]] == References == {{Asia-law-stub}} {{Malaysia-stub}} [[Category:Judiciary of Malaysia]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
'''Radio SEAC''' was the war time radio station operated by the Allied [[South East Asia Command]] (SEAC) that took over the operations of [[Colombo Radio]], a Ceylonese radio station launched in 1925. Radio programs were broadcast across Asia to the allied forces and to the people of [[British India|India]] and [[South Asia]].
Radio SEAC was handed over to the Government of [[Ceylon]] after [[World War II]] who changed the name to [[Radio Ceylon]]. The station is the oldest radio station in Asia (world's second oldest). Millions tuned into Radio SEAC and subsequently Radio Ceylon.
==See also==
*[[Radio Ceylon]]
== External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060321233514/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/12/21/fea10.htm SLBC-creating new waves of history] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080925204950/http://www.dailynews.lk/2005/12/27/fea02.htm Eighty Years of Broadcasting in Sri Lanka] * [http://www.slbc.lk Sri Lanka Broadcasting Corporation]
{{coord missing|Sri Lanka}}
[[Category:Radio stations in Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Radio during World War II]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1925]] [[Category:Ceylon in World War II]] [[Category:British Empire in World War II]] {{SriLanka-stub}} {{Asia-radio-station-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=April 2011}} {{ infobox company | name = Saudi Advanced Industries Company (SAIC)
الشركة السعودية للصناعات المتطورة | logo = | caption = | type = [[Public company|Public]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1987 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Riyadh]] | location_country = [[Saudi Arabia]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = [[Khalid Al-Shathry]] (Chairman)
[[Abdulrahman Al Garawi]] (Managing Director)
[[Saad Ammash Al-Shammary]] (General Manager) | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = http://www.saic.com.sa | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Saudi Advanced Industries Company''' is an industrial [[investment]] vehicle of the U.S. Peace Shield defense offset program. The company was formed in 1987, and invests in [[technology]] companies in [[Saudi Arabia]]. It also holds interests in AlSalam Aircraft Company and the Aircraft Accessories & Components Company, both in Saudi Arabia.[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/quote?ticker=SAIC:AB] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.saic.com.sa/ Official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Saudi Advanced Industries Company}} [[Category:1987 establishments in Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Companies of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Companies established in 1987]] [[Category:Companies listed on Tadawul]] [[Category:Investment companies of Saudi Arabia]] [[Category:Technology companies of Saudi Arabia]] {{Industry-stub}} {{Asia-company-stub}} {{Saudi-stub}}

Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Taxation|expanded=International}} The problem of tax equalisation arises when an individual is working for an international company and starts to work abroad his home country. There are questions of who should pay taxes and how much should he pay. Usually, the individual is receiving a net pay, which is the money he would have received in his home country after taxation. However, the company is obliged to pay taxes for its employee. If they are working in a country with lower taxes, the company takes the savings. On the other hand, if they work in country with higher taxation, the company pays the excess. Either way, the amount received by the employee is same. If the policy only benefits the employee (reducing taxes if working abroad results in higher taxes, but not raising them if working abroad results in lower taxes), then it is referred to as a '''tax protection''' policy.
The term "tax equalization" is also used by some American states, such as [http://www.terc.ne.gov/ Nebraska] and [https://web.archive.org/web/20090713045737/http://www.co.ward.nd.us/taxequalization/ North Dakota] to refer to property [[Real estate appraisal|appraisal]] in the context of [[property tax]].
== Theory == The idea is that an individual´s income stays same.There are some steps how to determine the tax:
Calculate the amount of money paid on taxes in individual´s home country. This sum of money is the hypothetical tax liability.
Reduce the pay of the individual by his/her tax liability.
Add any allowance that is necessary to be paid while he is abroad as a result of an assignment. This is his/her net assignment pay. == Complications== Although it may appear easy to calculate your net pay, there are some other difficulties influencing your net pay. For example, if you are using company car in your home country, should you receive some subsidies when you are abroad and unable to use it? Or how is your partner´s income treated?
For whom is the split-year tax system beneficial?
What if an individual leaves the company?
Does your tax equalisation policy discourage individuals from acquiring property abroad?
and many more.
== Practice == In practice, it is usually about agreement of both sides. Both parties should know on which basis is the tax calculated. After this is calculated, the amount is deducted from individual´s net pay on a regular basis throughout his assignment abroad. It is common, that the company deducts a hypothetical liability at the beginning of the year and then undertakes tax reconciliation at the end of the year.
== References == * [http://www.expatexchange.com/lib.cfm?articleID=718 Tax Equalization], Tax Advice by Tim Lenneman, CPA * [http://www.internationalhradviser.com/storage/downloads/What%20Is%20Tax%20Equalisation%20BDO.pdf], What is tax equalization by Andrew Bailey
[[Category:International taxation]]

page.title: Union des Radios et Televisions Libres du Mali

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
'''URTEL''' is an acronym for ''Union des Radios et Televisions Libres du Mali'', the agency responsible for regulating television and radio transmission operations in [[Mali]].
==Operations== URKEL is affiliated with the following [[NGOs]], which together form the ''Comité d’Appui à la Radio pour le Développement'', or "CARD".[http://urtel.radio.org.ml./article.php3?id_article=5]
*[[ACDI]] *[[Africare]] *[[Fondation Fredrich Ebert]] *[[Helen Keller International]] *[[Institut Panos]] *[[Plan International]] *[[PNUD]] *[[Population Médias Center]] *[[Population Services International]] *[[SNV Netherlands Development Organisation]] *[[UNESCO]] *[[Unicef Mali]] *[[USAID Mali]]
==See also== *[[Communications in Mali]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * Peter Coles, [https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg14819984.100-turn-your-radio-on.html Turn your radio on]. [[New Scientist]], 7 October 1995. * [http://www.freedomhouse.org/modules/mod_call_dsp_country-fiw.cfm?year=2007&country=7225 Mali (2007)]: [[Freedom House]] report. * [http://www.rsf.org/article.php3?id_article=18728 Six radio station staff freed on completing sentences: Mali]. [[Reporters Without Borders]], 26 September 2006. * [https://www.forbes.com/global/2002/0204/042.html Silicon Mali]. Silvia Sansoni, [[Forbes]] 02.04.02. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080314110336/http://voanews.com/english/archive/2005-09/2005-09-13-Mali-training.cfm VOA Training African Affiliates: Broadcasters’ Fiscal Health Key ‘To Guarantee Pluralism’]. [[Voice of America]], 13 September 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070608105722/http://aec.msu.edu/fs2/fact/idwp54l.htm Mali Market Information Study] FOOD SECURITY II COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT between U.S. AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT and MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY: IN-COUNTRY TIME PERIOD: JULY 1987 - DECEMBER 1994. ''statistical evidence is consistent with anecdotal reports from both farmers and traders that the SIM radio broadcasts have fundamentally changed bargaining relationships between traders and farmers, forcing traders to offer more competitive prices in isolated rural markets.'' * Cécile Leguy. [http://inscribe.iupress.org/doi/abs/10.2979/RAL.2007.38.3.136?cookieSet=1&journalCode=ral Revitalizing the Oral Tradition: Stories Broadcast by Radio Parana (San, Mali)]. Research in African Literatures, Fall 2007, Vol. 38, No. 3, Pages 136-147. *[http://www.africa.upenn.edu/Electronic/Radio_Bamakan_12700.html Radio Bamakan - Mali]. InteRadio, Vol. 5, No.2, June 1993.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070312082256/http://urtel.radio.org.ml/ URTEL {{fr icon}} ]
[[Category:Media in Mali]] [[Category:Government of Mali]] [[Category:Organisations based in Mali]] [[Category:Communications authorities]]
{{Mali-stub}} {{Africa-org-stub}}

[[File:1991 CPA 6373.jpg|300px|thumb|Postage stamp showing Latvian traditional instruments, amongst those the ģīga]] The '''ģīga''' or '''divstīdzis''' is a two-stringed bowed zither found in [[Latvia]].
The instrument is descended from the [[psalmodicon]] ({{lang-lv|vienstīdzis}} or ''manihorka''), a bowed [[monochord]] developed in [[Sweden]] in 1829 for liturgical singing. From there it filtered down to the Latvian peasantry who sometimes added a second string for harmony.<ref>Folklora.lv</ref>
==See also== *[[Fiðla]], a bowed zither native to Iceland
==Sources== *[http://folklora.lv/muzikas/giga/en.shtml Folklora.lv]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Giga}} [[Category:Latvian musical instruments]] [[Category:Bowed box zithers]]
